Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Digitizing the Fossil Insects of LA: Critical Additions to the Fossil Insect Collaborative
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to digitize five fossil insect collections from the United States, Germany, and Canada. These efforts will make nearly 27,000 new specimen records digitally available online. Collectively, these data will complement the previously awarded Fossil Insect Collaborative (FIC) Digitization (FIC) TCN by filling gaps in the existing dataset, and make these otherwise difficult to access collections significantly more visible to the interested public and research community. This information will facilitate current research aimed at better understanding the globally most diverse group of animals in the context of past, present, and future environments. Results of this project will be communicated to the public through museum events and K-12 classroom programming, ongoing partnership with local avocational paleontologists, and other educational resources developed by the FIC-TCN, including iDigPaleo.

The fossil insect collections to be digitized through this award include compression fossils from the Oligocene Rott Formation ("Statz Collection") of Germany, silicified insects from the Miocene Barstow Formation of California, asphalt-preserved insects from the Pleistocene deposits of Rancho La Brea and McKittrick in California, and lignite-associated insects of Lynn Creek, British Columbia. Notably, these collections are largely historic in nature and include 1,819 type specimens that have been inaccessible for taxonomic re-evaluation by the international research community for decades. Further, the Rott fauna represents an important calibration point in understanding fossil insect diversity trends with respect to global climate transitions (the primary research theme of the FIC-TCN), and the Barstow fauna is taphonomically distinct, as it includes three-dimensionally silicified insect body fossils. Digitization will involve cataloging 10,906 specimens and selectively imaging 6,207 specimens, as well as making available an additional 15,684 specimen records from the La Brea Tar Pits and Museum in this data aggregation, all of which will be made available online via the national resource for Advancing Digitization of Biodiversity Collections (http://www.idigbio.com).

Institution.Name: Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY FOUNDATION

Performance_Institution.Name: Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History Foundation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ?Fossil Insects of LA? digitization project (2017-2020) was a Partner to Existing Network (PEN) of the Fossil Insect Collaborative Thematic Collections Network (FIC-TCN) (2013-2020). It improved the digital accessibility of two of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County?s (NHMLA) paleontology collections, including a subset of those housed in the Invertebrate Paleontology department and at Rancho La Brea. This interdepartmental collaboration was the first of its kind for the NHMLA and successfully made over 27,000 digital specimen occurrence records and over 7,500 images publicly available to biodiversity aggregators through iDigBio?s installation of the Integrated Publishing Toolkit (http://ipt.idigbio.org).

 

The Fossil Insects of LA project contributed significantly to the FIC-TCN by expanding its coverage in geologic time and geographic scope, as well as its outreach potential. Specifically, the funded project allowed LACMIP?s large and unique research-quality collection of fossil insects to be fully catalogued and digitally imaged. This resulted in the digitization of over 8,500 occurrence records and over 7,400 images from five key collections, including: 1) the late Oligocene Rott Formation of Germany (known as the ?Statz Collection?); 2) the middle Miocene Barstow silicified arthropod fauna of California; and the three Quaternary insect assemblages from 3) Rancho La Brea, 4) the McKittrick asphalt seeps, and 5) Lynn Creek, British Columbia. Additionally, a large dataset from the Rancho La Brea Tar Pits and Museum was mobilized, which included over 18,600 specimen occurrence records and nearly 400 images of subfossil insects and other closely related arthropods. Critically, this effort enabled both the LACMIP collections and Rancho La Brea to share digital collections data online for the first time, which is an activity that can now continue beyond the lifespan of the funded project.

 

The Fossil Insects of LA project contributed to the outreach impact of the FIC-TCN. Products of this PEN and the TCN were featured at large and small museum events over the course of the project, two of which were attended by over 13,000 museum visitors. Four presentations directly related to this project were made to professional audiences, as well as a fifth presentation made internally. In collaboration with external partners, the Fossil Insects of LA project played a key role in extending the application of the products created by the FIC-TCN through novel applications of the ePANDDA API (another NSF-funded initiative, NSF 1541028) in conjunction with the Paleobiology Database. Lastly, local college students, recent graduates, and members of the avocational paleontological community were actively engaged in the project throughout its duration.

 


Last Modified: 06/16/2020
Modified by: Lindsay J Walker

The Fossil Insects of LA project contributed significantly to the FIC-TCN by expanding its coverage in geologic time and geographic scope, as well as its outreach potential. Specifically, the funded project allowed LACMIP?s large and unique research-quality collection of fossil insects to be fully catalogued and digitally imaged. Critically, this effort enabled both the LACMIP collections and Rancho La Brea to share digital collections data online for the first time, which is an activity that can now continue beyond the lifespan of the funded project. The Fossil Insects of LA project contributed to the outreach impact of the FIC-TCN. Products of this PEN and the TCN were featured at large and small museum events over the course of the project, two of which were attended by over 13,000 museum visitors.
